body:
Read your Bible. Pick one you can understand. Seriously, just go to a book store, leaf through several translations and buy the one you can actually understand.

I will say though, that based on your question, I really think you'd also enjoy Mere Christianity by C.S. Lewis, and it's likely to answer this and maybe a few questions you don't even know you have yet.

body: Technically anything that emphasizes faith apart from the religious institution and human authority is "Gnosticism", meaning most of the bible authors, including Jesus, are undoubtedly gnostic, and almost every Christian outside of catholic/orthodox denominations is gnostic at least partially. However usually believers use the word gnostic much more narrowly, to refer to someone who denies the resurrection and most of the miracles and atonement, and believes in paganism and other very strange things.

body: Paul is unlikely to have encountered such sects during his lifetime. While there are letters of "Paul" which denounce Marcionism (Timothy and Titus), they are very obviously written by 2nd century church fathers specifically to combat it. While Paul would certainly have rebuked it himself, he was not a reactionary who just said everything the opposite of Marcion or whoever "the enemy" was at the time. Paul disagrees with Marcion, but also agrees with him in important ways which the church fathers sought to obscure.

body:
Don't join a denomination. There are to be no divisions among us. Get out of the political trap while you still can. False siblings and televangelist pharisees are all over the place on a mission to spy on the freedom we have in the Anointed One. They want to exhort people in the name of religion and gain power and money. In New Testament times Christians met in house churches, hiding underground from the Romans and the Jewish fundamentalists who burned them alive on the streets if they found them. The churches were not churches, they were meetings and a spiritual body. It was not "everyone sit down and listen to the pastor" like in pagan temples. The church is the body of believers, the assembly, which transcends all worldly divisions. Not a denomination, not a pope, not a political platform, not any secular authority.

Do not think you will be saved by sacraments or prayers. God already knows what you would pray for. And you must be immersed with the holy spirit and fire, not water. Salvation is by faith. Anyone who calls on the name of 𐤉𐤄𐤅𐤄 will be saved.

body: I would recommend using an interlinear. Most english translations are biased towards the views of the translators (for example many bibles soften the prophets' attacks on counterfeit scriptures). They also tend to use very "religious" terminology (ex. they treat Χριστος like a last name) and extremely formal language which makes everything hard to understand, to the point where the interlinears and original languages are actually easier reads. Being aware of textual variants and learning to spot later additions or changes to the text is not a bad idea either.

body:
Not to seem pedantic but I get the feeling you've never even given the Nag Hamadi library a once over. Gnostics were a specific sect, and had specific beliefs, and even believed in the embodiment and the resurrection.

I've not seen much space in the orthodox to entertain discussions on the Universe. It's all relegated to this planet, whereas, Gnosticism leaves plenty of space to help people understand space.

Admittedly I'm not even close to being a scholar on either topic, but I think it's intriguing how quickly it's dismissed cause daddy prophet said so. The Catholic church is obviously a mortal creation and a mortal serving institution. Might as well believe we invaded Iraq for WMD's if you're just gonna take the orthodox at face value.

parent.body: Technically anything that emphasizes faith apart from the religious institution and human authority is "Gnosticism", meaning most of the bible authors, including Jesus, are undoubtedly gnostic, and almost every Christian outside of catholic/orthodox denominations is gnostic at least partially. However usually believers use the word gnostic much more narrowly, to refer to someone who denies the resurrection and most of the miracles and atonement, and believes in paganism and other very strange things.

parent.body: Paul is unlikely to have encountered such sects during his lifetime. While there are letters of "Paul" which denounce Marcionism (Timothy and Titus), they are very obviously written by 2nd century church fathers specifically to combat it. While Paul would certainly have rebuked it himself, he was not a reactionary who just said everything the opposite of Marcion or whoever "the enemy" was at the time. Paul disagrees with Marcion, but also agrees with him in important ways which the church fathers sought to obscure.

parent.body:
Don't join a denomination. There are to be no divisions among us. Get out of the political trap while you still can. False siblings and televangelist pharisees are all over the place on a mission to spy on the freedom we have in the Anointed One. They want to exhort people in the name of religion and gain power and money. In New Testament times Christians met in house churches, hiding underground from the Romans and the Jewish fundamentalists who burned them alive on the streets if they found them. The churches were not churches, they were meetings and a spiritual body. It was not "everyone sit down and listen to the pastor" like in pagan temples. The church is the body of believers, the assembly, which transcends all worldly divisions. Not a denomination, not a pope, not a political platform, not any secular authority.

Do not think you will be saved by sacraments or prayers. God already knows what you would pray for. And you must be immersed with the holy spirit and fire, not water. Salvation is by faith. Anyone who calls on the name of 𐤉𐤄𐤅𐤄 will be saved.

body: I'd recommend an interlinear, bonus points if it shows textual variants. The reason I say this is because all translations are biased towards the views of the translator, sometimes even blatantly. Another minor reason is that bible translations tend to translate into excessively formal language and use religious terms for what was originally everyday words, making everything extremely confusing to the point where the original is easier to read. Do not buy a bible, that is supporting the greedy religious organizations. Use free websites, there are a lot of them.

body:
![](https://media.giphy.com/media/xUPGcMzwkOY01nj6hi/100w.gif)

A pleasure to hear. Be blessed!

Here's a quick primer on translation differences: https://youtu.be/bmO0Fwa74QM

I personally like the NASB. 

That channel is also a great source for distilling and following themes throughout the bible and has summaries of the different books. 

Besides reading your Bible, I'd recommend this theology book: Bible Doctrine, Essential Teachings of the Christian Faith: https://www.amazon.com/Bible-Doctrine-Wayne-Grudem/dp/0310222338/ref=pd_sim_b_3 

It explains Christian understandings of God and the Bible etc using biblical texts and presents differing ideas from different Christian 'schools of thought'. Things like what is the Trinity? What is grace? What are the gifts of the Holy Spirit? etc. I think it presents itself based in scripture and as objectively as one might. It was gifted to me by an older Christian and I have enjoyed it a lot. 

As far as "dominations". I consider myself "non-dominational". I believe in what the Bible says and form my own opinions on it, my relationship with God is most ultimately between Him and me—I answer to Him first and last. There is no man between me and God but Jesus. I don't believe the "Pope" is a biblical idea. I don't believe one man represents God's authoritative voice on earth. The Bible presents local bodies of church leadership as a group of accountable elders. This would put me in the "protestant" camp, because I do not follow the Catholic church's unique traditions or teachings. I agree with the man Martin Luther's protest of reformation to the corruption and errancy of the Catholic church. 

https://www.luther.de/en/95thesen.html

https://www.history.com/topics/reformation/martin-luther-and-the-95-theses 

As far as picking a local church, most churches have a list of stated beliefs. Read them and see if that sounds biblical to you and pray about it. And if you attend and think you feel the presence of God there and in the people—that's an excellent sign. 

I wish you well on your journey and pray you experience the transforming power of God's wisdom, love, and aid in your life and on your future. Don't sweat the details too much and trust that the Holy Spirit can guide you.

body:
Unfortunately, we don't have any of the autographs. The church probably burned them along with all the other texts that didn't conform to their version. But we do have the bulk of truth remaining, just alongside forgeries. We know the nature of God and the two or one commandments (depending on how you look at it), and we know about atonement and the resurrection and such and such. But as with anything, you have to use discernment according to those core pillars of faith. However, almost every time I come across a suspicious passage in the bible, there are significant signs of it being a later addition. It's not good to put full trust in the writers anyway; even though they were good people, they were not God, and there's a chance they were wrong about something. These days people practically treat them as if they are more divine than Jesus himself, especially Paul but also Peter, David, Moses, etc (which in my opinion shows they see them as mythological figures and not real historical people).

By "progression from sociopathic paganism to agape faith" I meant that in the most recent texts, the new testament, you have a few suspicious passages in the authentic books, maybe a fake chapter or two, etc, but it's mostly in agreement with the fundamental principles it lays out. However in the old testament, in the oldest books you have all kinds of completely outlandish laws and stories. "God" says to make animal sacrifices because of the "pleasing aroma" and commands genocide and slaughtering of children. "Moses" condones sex slavery and pedophilia, says to burn people at the stake, and that eunuchs, blind people, or anyone with any kind of disability whatsoever is an abomination and should go kill themselves. The true parts may actually be in the minority here. But the later you go, the less of this there is, and the latter, true theme becomes more prevalent. There are less contradictions and the brutality and cruelty disappears. The prophets begin to denounce these corruptions, with Jeremiah addressing the situation directly. By the time you get to the new testament it's just a few cringey passages here and there with the rest being pure. The reason for this is that the later texts are more recent, and the older ones have had more time to be corrupted by scribes.

body: This is mainly because Satan never gave me what I truly wanted: happiness. Sure, he gave me money, girls, etc, but I was never truly happy. He only gave me short term highs, but it was never anything long term. A few days after that post, I found myself thinking of this more and more. I eventually looked into Christianity and started rereading the Bible. When I got to the part where Satan was making Adam and Eve eat the forbidden fruit, and I noticed something I never had before: this was almost exactly like my experience. He was giving them temporary knowledge and pretty much damning them to hell, and I feel like he did the same to me. This is why I changed my mind

body: I hate to break it to you, but God's goal isn't to make you happy either. Well it is, but for now that is not the priority. This is a broken world and it's difficult to realize just how far it's fallen without trials. And I mean *endless* trials. This is not your home, you are not meant to be happy here. Much of this world is left up to chance, and some people get lucky and can live a comfortable but annoying life, and a select few have a shot at being happy, but otherwise it's a grim situation. And be warned, Satan often makes the lives of the faithful, especially new converts, utterly fall apart like Job's to try and break their faith.

body: Crystal, you're talking about things you know nothing about. CS Lewis is a random author, he is not an ancient tome from thousands of years ago tied to a long history of a resurging kingdom of believers. The canon existed long before the forming of the Vatican, such as via the Samaritan Pentateuch & Dead Sea Scrolls which date to 250BC minimum, with carbon dating indicating the latter is far older than even 400BC. I'd like to see a list of NT references to the apocrypha so I can study them, but I hope you're not planning to send vagueries like Solomon's Wisdom, where the references can be for literally anything. Beyond that, its physically impossible for the NT to have copied the Talmud, because the Talmud was written from 300-500AD. And if you mean to propose the Talmud was an oral tradition, you'd have a horde of scholars questioning you on the legitimacy of that claim, considering the very concept of such a thing didn't emerge until over 1000 years after Moses in spite of the claim he was the one who received it. To accept the Talmud as a hidden law you'd also have to accept the book of Jubilees, and nobody does that. There is so much you need to study and learn before judging others. Why lurk on the Christianity page only to get egg on your face? I can send you some resources if you'd like to learn more.

body:
> CS Lewis is a random author, he is not an ancient tome from thousands of years ago tied to a long history of a resurging kingdom of believers.

Why does it have to be thousands of years old? Do you mean to say Jesus was just some random guy until 1000 AD? And I assume you believe no one but Jesus was ever perfect. If so, why do you still treat certain people as if they're infallible?

> Samaritan Pentateuch & Dead Sea Scrolls

Both of those prove my point. The Samaritans were one such group that accepted a certain canon of books, only Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy. Given that the rest of the old testament had been written by then, how does the Samaritan Pentateuch prove anything? And the Dead Sea Scrolls, well let's see here, we have Tobit, Enoch, Jubilees which you mentioned, the epistle of Jeremiah, a lost book of Noah, Sirach, and a whole host of books not included in our bible. Many of which are also referenced in the New Testament.

> its physically impossible for the NT to have copied the Talmud, because the Talmud was written from 300-500AD.

By "talmud" I mean whatever Judaic texts were circulating at the time. It doesn't have to be the same as the one they use today.

> I'd like to see a list of NT references to the apocrypha so I can study them

I can't spend all day on this but I'll provide you with a few.

Jude 1:14: Enoch, the seventh from Adam, also prophesied about them: “Behold, the Lord is coming with myriads of His holy ones to execute judgment on everyone, and to convict all the ungodly of every ungodly act of wickedness and every harsh word spoken against Him by ungodly sinners.”

1 Enoch 1:9: Behold, he comes with the myriads of his holy ones, to execute judgment on all, and to destroy all the wicked, and to convict all flesh for all the wicked deeds that they have done, and the proud and hard words that wicked sinners spoke against him.

4 Ezra 7: For I made the world for their sake, and when Adam transgressed my statutes, what had been made was judged. And so the entrances of this world were made narrow and sorrowful and toilsome; they are few and evil, full of dangers and involved in great hardships. But the entrances of the greater world are broad and safe, and yield the fruit of immortality. Therefore unless the living pass through the difficult and futile experiences, they can never receive those things that have been reserved for them.

Multiple NT allusions to the broad and narrow way

4 Ezra 7: For you have a treasure of works stored up with the Most High, but it will not be shown to you until the last times.

NT: Store up treasure in heaven

There are a LOT more, but you have to be looking in the right places, not the plethora of sites that try to twist it into saying they don't exist.

> There is so much you need to study and learn before judging others.

I haven't judged anyone here.

parent.body: Crystal, you're talking about things you know nothing about. CS Lewis is a random author, he is not an ancient tome from thousands of years ago tied to a long history of a resurging kingdom of believers. The canon existed long before the forming of the Vatican, such as via the Samaritan Pentateuch & Dead Sea Scrolls which date to 250BC minimum, with carbon dating indicating the latter is far older than even 400BC. I'd like to see a list of NT references to the apocrypha so I can study them, but I hope you're not planning to send vagueries like Solomon's Wisdom, where the references can be for literally anything. Beyond that, its physically impossible for the NT to have copied the Talmud, because the Talmud was written from 300-500AD. And if you mean to propose the Talmud was an oral tradition, you'd have a horde of scholars questioning you on the legitimacy of that claim, considering the very concept of such a thing didn't emerge until over 1000 years after Moses in spite of the claim he was the one who received it. To accept the Talmud as a hidden law you'd also have to accept the book of Jubilees, and nobody does that. There is so much you need to study and learn before judging others. Why lurk on the Christianity page only to get egg on your face? I can send you some resources if you'd like to learn more.

body:
Nothing you're saying is making sense. You believe it is, but its not. Assumptions, rhetorical questions, and framing the issues are not valid points. You're not making any.

For example, you claim the canon was made in 400, I just indicated that was not the case. Repeating my points to sidestep your flaws is tedious.

Jude referring to Enoch is the only one that's widely known and debunked so why bring it up? 1st Enoch is part of the Pseudepigrapha, so its by default not inspired. If that were the case you'd have to say Epimenides of Cnossoss was inspired XD If you consider quotes to be endorsements, then you're holding yourself to a different standard than others, the peak of hypocrisy.

And claiming the Ezra similarity connotes canonicity faces an identical issue. You're treating a reference as if its an endorsement. If that was the case, then John's reference to Logos would endorse the Greek meaning of the term. IN REALITY, John was referencing Logos are clarifying what it truly is. 

If a reference is an endorsement, then you'd have to read meaning into the text that is patently antithetical to the context. Beyond that, it would require a level of hypocrisy that I know you try to avoid.

Surely you know these things, so why do you create arbitrary standards for others, that you yourself do not follow?

parent.body:
> CS Lewis is a random author, he is not an ancient tome from thousands of years ago tied to a long history of a resurging kingdom of believers.

Why does it have to be thousands of years old? Do you mean to say Jesus was just some random guy until 1000 AD? And I assume you believe no one but Jesus was ever perfect. If so, why do you still treat certain people as if they're infallible?

> Samaritan Pentateuch & Dead Sea Scrolls

Both of those prove my point. The Samaritans were one such group that accepted a certain canon of books, only Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy. Given that the rest of the old testament had been written by then, how does the Samaritan Pentateuch prove anything? And the Dead Sea Scrolls, well let's see here, we have Tobit, Enoch, Jubilees which you mentioned, the epistle of Jeremiah, a lost book of Noah, Sirach, and a whole host of books not included in our bible. Many of which are also referenced in the New Testament.

> its physically impossible for the NT to have copied the Talmud, because the Talmud was written from 300-500AD.

By "talmud" I mean whatever Judaic texts were circulating at the time. It doesn't have to be the same as the one they use today.

> I'd like to see a list of NT references to the apocrypha so I can study them

I can't spend all day on this but I'll provide you with a few.

Jude 1:14: Enoch, the seventh from Adam, also prophesied about them: “Behold, the Lord is coming with myriads of His holy ones to execute judgment on everyone, and to convict all the ungodly of every ungodly act of wickedness and every harsh word spoken against Him by ungodly sinners.”

1 Enoch 1:9: Behold, he comes with the myriads of his holy ones, to execute judgment on all, and to destroy all the wicked, and to convict all flesh for all the wicked deeds that they have done, and the proud and hard words that wicked sinners spoke against him.

4 Ezra 7: For I made the world for their sake, and when Adam transgressed my statutes, what had been made was judged. And so the entrances of this world were made narrow and sorrowful and toilsome; they are few and evil, full of dangers and involved in great hardships. But the entrances of the greater world are broad and safe, and yield the fruit of immortality. Therefore unless the living pass through the difficult and futile experiences, they can never receive those things that have been reserved for them.

Multiple NT allusions to the broad and narrow way

4 Ezra 7: For you have a treasure of works stored up with the Most High, but it will not be shown to you until the last times.

NT: Store up treasure in heaven

There are a LOT more, but you have to be looking in the right places, not the plethora of sites that try to twist it into saying they don't exist.

> There is so much you need to study and learn before judging others.

I haven't judged anyone here.

body:
> Jude referring to Enoch is the only one that's widely known and debunked so why bring it up?

It's not debunked. "Jude" here quotes Enoch literally word for word, and as an authoritative source. There's no other way to interpret this one. This one is not simply used to allude to or take an idea from a text, it quotes a prophecy.

> And claiming the Ezra similarity connotes canonicity faces an identical issue. You're treating a reference as if its an endorsement.

In most of the cases, sparing a few like the Enoch one, I'm not. But the point is that they're obviously familiar with such texts and find them useful. It does *not* mean they are perfect, only that they contain truth. Thus my point, because it shows how they treated "the writings", like written works *by people*, not dropped out of the sky by God (and the texts themselves mostly straight up say this). And this classification makes up most of the books in our biblical canon.

And no, the canon was not settled before 382 AD. Before that the legitimacy of different books was regularly disputed. That is historical fact. In fact the first "bible" compiled was by a gnostic!

body:
> When I say your Jude point is debunked, its because it does not prove your central claim. And if you've abandoned that claim, there really is no reason to continue.

When did I abandon that claim? You're just deflecting at this point, whoever wrote Jude would not have confidently quoted a prophesy from 1 Enoch if he didn't believe it to be authentic. And he did, so obviously he thought 1 Enoch was true. This book is not in our canon, so since the writer of Jude disagrees with our canon then it obviously didn't exist back then, or was different from ours which is practically the same thing.

Again, I have to remind you of the topic you brought up. The canonicity of the scripture. You brought up apocryphal references to say the canon was in disarray, and as evidence, you brought up Jude. When I say your Jude point is debunked, its because it does not prove your central claim. And if you've abandoned that claim, there really is no reason to continue.

The Pseudepigrapha point debunks your second claim. And simply saying "No it was not" is not a counter-point, its just clinging to a debunked stance :P

parent.body:
> When I say your Jude point is debunked, its because it does not prove your central claim. And if you've abandoned that claim, there really is no reason to continue.

When did I abandon that claim? You're just deflecting at this point, whoever wrote Jude would not have confidently quoted a prophesy from 1 Enoch if he didn't believe it to be authentic. And he did, so obviously he thought 1 Enoch was true. This book is not in our canon, so since the writer of Jude disagrees with our canon then it obviously didn't exist back then, or was different from ours which is practically the same thing.

body:
"If that were the case you'd have to say Epimenides of Cnossoss was inspired XD If you consider quotes to be endorsements, then you're holding yourself to a different standard than others, the peak of hypocrisy."

So you are skimming. Or, you believe that Aratus, Menander, Epimenides, and a million others were also viewed as inspired. You would have no proof for that claim outside of assumptions, but hey, its your twisted logic.

Not to mention the quote in question is simply “Behold, the Lord came with many thousands of His holy ones”. This could easily be a case identical to Acts 20:35. A saying that was commonly known via tradition but not written into the scripture. As you put it earlier "Talmudic" in nature. And considering first Enoch was written in the 100s BC, its highly likely this was the case. This is not outside of Christian Orthodoxy, as Jesus himself celebrated Hanukkah, a holiday outlined outside of the Old Testament. Yet, Jesus himself opposed Talmudic rules and traditions constantly. 

In simple terms - referencing tradition is not the same as considering it inspired. 

And another point on your contention Enoch may be Canon, it wasn't included in the Masoretic Texts, The Septuagint, or any known canon historically. It may have been read, but historically, the jews viewed it as separate from the canon of scripture.

body:
> So you are skimming. Or, you believe that Aratus, Menander, Epimenides, and a million others were also viewed as inspired. You would have no proof for that claim outside of assumptions, but hey, its your twisted logic.

No, I believe that the writers believed those *parts* were true. The only "inspired" kind of work is prophecy.

> Hanukkah, a holiday outlined outside of the Old Testament

In the apocryphal books of Maccabees.

> And another point on your contention Enoch may be Canon, it wasn't included in the Masoretic Texts, The Septuagint, or any known canon historically. It may have been read, but historically, the jews viewed it as separate from the canon of scripture.

The author of Jude would certainly disagree with you, seeing how he refers to it authoritatively. This is different from alluding to parts of writings as mentioned above. He quotes it for support of his claims, meaning he viewed it as factual. And you are right that *some* jews viewed it as fraudulent, but others saw it as true. In fact, a group of Jews called "Beta Israel" as well as Ethiopian Christians still consider Enoch scripture to this day. Thus my point, there was no canon, things were debated.

He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God.

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.
guild.name: Christianity
